qas.question: What event is regarded as a landmark in the development of modern nationalism?
If possessing a language leads to a group being regarded as a separate people, what political arrangement presumably follows?
What political arrangement is associated with being a dialect-speaking sub-group?
Along with political controversy, what can the distinction between a language and dialect sometimes lead to?
Since which revolution has Ancient Nationalism especially been developed?
What has failed to make a distinction between the terms language and dialect?
On which basis is the distinction between language and dialect more often made?

plausible_answers.text: political controversy, or even armed conflict.

qas.question: What can the distinction between regional autonomy and dialect lead to?

plausible_answers.text: political controversy, or even armed conflict.

qas.question: What can the distinction between regional autonomy and the French Revolution lead to?

context: <b5_0>Modern Nationalism<b5_0/>, as developed especially since <a0_0>the <b4_0>French Revolution<b4_0/><a0_0/>, has made the distinction between "language" and "dialect" an issue of great political importance. A group speaking a separate "language" is often seen as having a greater claim to being a separate "people", and thus to be more deserving of <a1_0>its own independent state<a1_0/>, while a group speaking a "dialect" tends to be seen not as "a people" in its own right, but as a sub-group, part of a bigger people, which must content itself with <a2_0>regional autonomy<a2_0/>.[citation needed] The distinction between language and dialect is thus inevitably made at least as much on a political basis as on a <b6_0>linguistic one<b6_0/>, and can lead to great <b7_0><b8_0>political controversy, or even <a3_0>armed conflict<a3_0/>.
